title: Characterizing the range of the complex Monge-Ampère operator

sections.text:
#### Abstract

In this note, we solve the complex Monge-Ampère equation for measures with a pluripolar part in compact Kähler manifolds. This result generalizes the classical results obtained by Cegrell in bounded hyperconvex domains. We also discuss the properties of the complex Monge-Ampère operator in some special cases.

## 1. InTRODUCTION

Let $(X, \omega)$ be a Kähler manifold of complex dimension $n$, and let $\{\alpha\} \in H^{1,1}(X, \mathbb{R})$. The study of the complex Monge-Ampère type equation

$$
\left(\alpha+d d^{c} \varphi\right)^{n}=\mu
$$

has been one of the most important topics in Kähler geometry over the past few decades.

When $\alpha>0$ and $\mu$ is a smooth volume form, Yau [17] proved that (1.1) admits a unique smooth solution, solving the famous Calabi conjecture. In this case, the left-hand side of (1.1) is the classic $n$-th wedge product.

When the cohomology class $\{\alpha\}$ is allowed to be degenerate and the measure $\mu$ is nonsmooth but non-pluripolar, the solution of (1.1) is closely related to the singular Kähler-Einstein metric. To solve the corresponding equation, the concept of the non-pluripolar product plays a crucial role; see, for example, [5, 11, 13, 14]. In this setting, the left-hand side of (1.1) is given by the non-pluripolar product.

When $\alpha=\omega$ and $\mu$ are allowed to have a pluripolar part (see Corollary 4.2), many uncertainties arise. Coman, Guedj, and Zeriahi in [10] developed theories to consider related problems. An important concept is the domain of the definition of the complex Monge-Ampère operator $D M A(X, \omega)$, see [10, Page 394].

A special and interesting problem mentioned in [12, Question 12] is that when $X=\mathrm{BL}_{p} \mathbb{P}^{2}, p \in \mathbb{P}^{2}, 0<\alpha:=\omega \in-c_{1}\left(K_{X}\right)$ and $\mu:=[D] \wedge \omega / V$, where $D$ is a smooth anticanonical divisor, $[D]$ is the (1,1)-current integral along $D$ and $V$ is the normalized constant, can one find $\varphi \in D M A(X, \omega)$ such that $\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)=\mu$ ?

Motivated by these related problems, we study the complex Monge-Ampère equation with a measure that has a pluripolar part in this note. Our focus will be on the Blocki-Cegrell class $\mathcal{D}(X, \omega) \subset D M A(X, \omega)$ (see Definition 2.5).

In the recent paper [2], Andersson, Witt Nyström, and Wulcan introduced the finite non-pluripolar energy class $\mathcal{G}(X, \omega)$. They proved that $\mathcal{D}(X, \omega) \subset \mathcal{G}(X, \omega)$;

i.e., if $\varphi \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$, then $\varphi \in L^{1}\left(\left\langle\omega_{\varphi}^{i}\right\rangle \wedge \omega^{n-i}\right), i=0,1, \ldots, n-1$, see [2, Theorem 1.10].

In Section 3, we show that one benefit of [2, Theorem 1.10] is that the MongeAmpère operator on $\mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$ can be expressed via the non-pluripolar product. Furthermore, we present the corresponding generalized theorem.

Theorem 1.1. (=Theorem 3.2) Let $(X, \omega)$ be a compact Kähler manifold of complex dimension $n$, and let $\varphi_{i} \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega), i=1, \ldots, n$. Then, $\varphi_{1} \in L^{1}\left(\left\langle\left(\omega+d d^{c} \varphi_{2}\right) \wedge\right.\right.$ $\left.\ldots \wedge\left(\omega+d d^{c} \varphi_{n}\right)\right\rangle \wedge \omega\rangle$.

If $X$ is a compact Kähler surface and $\varphi, \psi \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$, then we have

$$
\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi, \psi)=\frac{1}{2}\left[\left(\omega+d d^{c} \varphi\right) \wedge\left\langle\omega+d d^{c} \psi\right\rangle+\left(\omega+d d^{c} \psi\right) \wedge\left\langle\omega+d d^{c} \varphi\right\rangle\right]
$$

The definition of $\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\cdot, \ldots, \cdot)$ can be found in Proposition 2.8.
Now, we consider the equation $\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)=\mu$, where $\varphi \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$ and $\mu$ is a normalized positive Borel measure. The Cegrell-Lebesgue decomposition, Corollary 4.2, indicates that we have the unique decomposition $\mu=\mu_{r}+\mu_{s}$, where $\mu_{r}$ is the non-pluripolar measure and $\mu_{s}=\mathbf{1}_{\{u=-\infty\}} \mu$ for some $u \in \operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega)$. A natural approach is to decompose $\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)$, then cosinder $\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)_{r}=\mu_{r}, \mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)_{s}=\mu_{s}$.

Thanks to [10, Corollary 1.8], which yields $\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)_{r}=\left\langle\omega_{\varphi}^{n}\right\rangle$ and $\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)_{s}=$ $\mathbf{1}_{\{\varphi=-\infty\}} \mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)$. Consequently, $\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)=\mu$ reduces to the following equations:

$$
\left\langle\omega_{\varphi}^{n}\right\rangle=\mu_{r} \text { and } \mathbf{1}_{\{\varphi=-\infty\}} \mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)=\mu_{s}, \varphi \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)
$$

Here the complex Monge-Ampère equation on the left-hand side, defined using the non-pluripolar product, is the familiar one. Thus, by combining it with the recent work of Darvas, Di Nezza, and Lu, [11], named relative pluripotential theory, we can solve the complex Monge-Ampère equation in a particular case.

Theorem 1.2. (=Theorem 4.7) Let $(X, \omega)$ be a compact Kähler manifold of complex dimension $n$ such that $\int_{X} \omega^{n}=1$, and let $\mu_{s}$ be a pluripolar measure on $X$ supported on some pluripolar set. If there exists $\varphi \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$ such that $\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)_{s}=\mu_{s}$, then for all $0 \leq f \in L^{p}\left(\omega^{n}\right), p>1$ such that $\int_{X} f \omega^{n}=1-\int_{X} \mu_{s}$, there exists a $\psi \in \operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega)$ that is the solution of the equation

$$
\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\psi)=f \omega^{n}+\mu_{s}, \psi \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)
$$

1.1. Comparing the classical result in the local setting. Let $\Omega \subset \mathbb{C}^{n}$ be a bounded hyperconvex domain. In $[1,6,7,8]$, a powerful theory for the Dirichlet problem of the complex Monge-Ampère equation on $\Omega$ was developed by several authors. In particular, the author was inspired by $[7,8]$ to consider the corresponding global result. Let $\mu$ be a positive Radon measure on $\Omega$. Cegrell proved the following result.

Theorem 1.3. ([8, Theorem 6.2]) Assume that $\mu=f\left(d d^{c} \varphi_{0}\right)^{n}+\mu_{s}$, where $\varphi_{0} \in$ $\mathcal{E}_{0}(\Omega)$ and $f \in L^{1}\left(\left(d d^{c} \varphi_{0}\right)^{n}\right)$. If there exists $\psi \in \mathcal{F}(\Omega)$ such that $\mathrm{MA}(\psi)=\mu_{s}$, then there exists $\varphi \in \mathcal{F}(\Omega)$ such that

$$
\mathrm{MA}(\varphi)=\mu
$$

The definition of $\mathcal{F}$ and $\mathcal{E}_{0}$ can be found in [8].

In the global setting, we replace the condition of the pluripolar part of $\mu$ with the condition that there exists $\varphi \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$ such that $\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)_{s}=\mu_{s}$ and require that $\mu_{r}=f \omega^{n}$ for some $0 \leq f \in L^{p}\left(\omega^{n}\right), p>1$.
1.2. Application. Let us focus on compact Kähler surfaces $(X, \omega)$. Assume that $\int_{X} \omega^{2}=1$, and let $\mu$ be a positive Borel measure on $X$, supported on a pluripolar set. Suppose there exists $\varphi \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$ such that $\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)=\mu$. By applying the two main theorems of this note, we obtain the following result.
Theorem 1.4. For any $0 \leq t \leq 1$ and $0 \leq f \in L^{p}\left(\omega^{2}\right), p>1$ such that $\int_{X} f \omega^{2}=1$, there exists $\psi_{f, t} \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$ that satisfies

$$
\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}\left(\psi_{f, t}\right)=(1-t) f \omega^{2}+t \mu
$$

1.3. Notation and Conventions. In this note, unless stated otherwise, we always assume that

- In the local setting, we consider the domain $\Omega$ in $\mathbb{C}^{n}$. In the global setting, we consider the compact Kähler manifolds $(X, \omega)$.
- The operator $d d^{c}:=\frac{\sqrt{-1}}{7} \partial \bar{\partial}$ is the normalized $\sqrt{-1} \partial \bar{\partial}$ operator.
- In the global setting, let $\operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega)$ be the set of upper semicontinuous functions $\varphi$ such that $d d^{c} \varphi+\omega \geq 0$. Plurisubharmonic functions are abbreviated as psh functions. When $\varphi \in \operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega)$, we abbreviate this by saying that $\varphi$ is a $\omega$-psh function.
- In any setting, we always assume that a measure is a positive Borel measure.

# 2. Preliminaries 

In pluripotential theory, the definition of the complex Monge-Ampère operator is a central issue. In the local setting, let $u_{1}, \ldots, u_{k}$ be a locally bounded psh function. Following the construction of Bedford-Taylor [6] (see also [14, Chapter 3]), where the current $d d^{c} u_{1} \wedge \ldots \wedge d d^{c} u_{k}$ is always well defined.
2.1. Non-pluripolar products. Let $(X, \omega)$ be a compact Kähler manifold. In the global setting, given the positive (1,1)-currents $\omega^{1}+d d^{c} \varphi_{1}, \ldots, \omega^{p}+d d^{c} \varphi_{p}$ on $X$. Assume $\omega^{i}, i=1, \ldots, p$ are Kähler forms and $\varphi_{i} \in \operatorname{PSH}\left(X, \omega^{i}\right)$. Following the construction of Bedford-Taylor [6] in the local setting, it was shown in [5] that the $d$-closed currents, so-called non-pluripolar product

$$
\left\langle\omega_{\varphi_{1}}^{1} \wedge \ldots \wedge \omega_{\varphi_{p}}^{p}\right\rangle
$$

is well-defined. By [5, Proposition 1.4], the non-pluripolar product is symmetric and multilinear. For a $\omega$-psh function $\varphi$, the non-pluripolar complex Monge-Ampère measure of $\varphi$ is $\left\langle\omega_{\varphi}^{n}\right\rangle:=\left\langle\left(\omega_{\varphi}\right)^{n}\right\rangle$.

Let $Y$ be a complex manifold. A set $A \subset Y$ is said to be pluripolar in $X$ if, for all $z \in A$, there exists a holomorphic coordinate chart $U$ near $z$ in $Y$ and a psh function $\varphi \in \operatorname{PSH}(U)$ such that $A \cap U \subset\{\varphi=-\infty\}$. A measure $\mu$ of $Y$ is said to be a non-pluripolar measure if $\int_{A} \mu=0$ for all pluripolar sets $A \subset Y$. In particular, when $p=n$, the measure $\left\langle\omega_{\varphi_{1}}^{1} \wedge \ldots \wedge \omega_{\varphi_{n}}^{n}\right\rangle$ mentioned above is non-pluripolar.

If $\varphi$ and $\psi$ are two $\omega$-psh functions on $X$, then $\psi$ is said to be less singular than $\varphi$, i.e., $\varphi \preceq \psi$, if they satisfy $\varphi \leq \psi+C$ for some $C \in \mathbb{R}$. We say that $\varphi$ has the same singularity as $\psi$, i.e., $\varphi \asymp \psi$, if $\varphi \preceq \psi$ and $\psi \preceq \varphi$. Then, we have the Volume comparison, due to Witt Nyström [16].

Theorem 2.1. Let $u, v \in \operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega)$ such that $v \preceq u$. Then,

$$
\int_{X}\left\langle\omega_{u}^{n}\right\rangle \geq \int_{X}\left\langle\omega_{v}^{n}\right\rangle
$$

In our study of the complex Monge-Ampère equation, the following envelope construction is essential:

Definition 2.2. Given $\psi, \varphi \in \operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega)$, the envelope with respect to singularity type $P_{\omega}[\psi]$ is defined by

$$
P_{\omega}[\psi]:=\left(\lim _{C \rightarrow+\infty} \sup \left\{u \in \operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega): u \leq \psi+C, u \leq 0\right\}^{*}\right)^{*}
$$

We summarize [11, Remark 3.4,Theorem 3.14] as follows.
Proposition 2.3. Let $\varphi \in \operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega)$. Then, we have
(i). $\int_{X}\left\langle\omega_{\varphi}^{n}\right\rangle=\int_{X}\left\langle\omega_{P_{\omega}[\varphi]}^{n}\right\rangle$,
(ii). Set $F_{\varphi}:=\left\{v \in \mathrm{PSH}^{-}(X, \omega): \varphi \preceq v \leq 0\right.$ and $\left.\int_{X}\left\langle\omega_{\varphi}^{n}\right\rangle=\int_{X}\left\langle\omega_{\varphi}^{n}\right\rangle\right\}$. One has $P_{\omega}[\varphi]=\sup F_{\varphi}$. In particular, $P_{\omega}[\varphi] \succeq \varphi$ and $P_{\omega}[\varphi]=P_{\omega}\left[P_{\omega}[\varphi]\right]$.

A $\omega$-psh function $\varphi$ is said to be a model potential if $P_{\omega}[\varphi]=\varphi$ and $\int_{X}\left\langle\omega_{\varphi}^{n}\right\rangle>0$. Clearly, $P_{\omega}[\varphi]$ is a model potential for all $\varphi \in \operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega)$ so that $\int_{X}\left\langle\omega_{\varphi}^{n}\right\rangle>0$.

Definition 2.4. Given a potential $\phi \in \operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega)$ such that $\int_{X} \omega_{\phi}^{n}>0$, the relative full mass class is defined by

$$
\mathcal{E}(X, \omega, \phi):=\left\{u \in \operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega): u \preceq \phi, \int_{X}\left\langle\omega_{u}^{n}\right\rangle=\int_{X}\left\langle\omega_{\phi}^{n}\right\rangle\right\}
$$

For the case in which $\phi$ is a model potential, Darvas, Di Nezza, and Lu [11] achieved a series of significant results on pluripotential theory and the (non-pluripolar product) complex Monge-Ampère equation in the relative full mass class $\mathcal{E}(X, \omega, \phi)^{1}$.
2.2. The complex Monge-Ampère operators on compact Kähler manifolds. In the local setting, assume that $\Omega \subset \mathbb{C}^{n}$ open. We denote $\mathcal{D}(\Omega) \subset \mathrm{PSH}^{-}(\Omega)$ as the largest subclass of the class of negative psh functions in which the complex Monge-Ampère operator can be well-defined, named the Blocki-Cegrell class; i.e., if $\varphi \in \mathcal{D}(\Omega)$, then there exists a measure $\mu$ such that for any sequence $\left\{\varphi_{j}\right\} \subset \operatorname{PSH} \cap L_{\text {loc }}^{\infty}(\Omega), \varphi_{j} \searrow \varphi$, the sequence $\left(d d^{c} \varphi_{j}\right)^{n}$ converges weakly to $\mu$. We denote $\operatorname{MA}(\varphi)=\left(d d^{c} \varphi\right)^{n}:=\mu$. In [3, 4], Blocki carefully studied $\mathcal{D}(\Omega)$. When $\Omega$ is a bounded hyperconvex domain, Blocki [4, Theorem 2.4] showed that $\mathcal{D}(\Omega)$ coincides with the class $\mathcal{E}(\Omega) \subset \mathrm{PSH}^{-}(\Omega)$ defined by Cegrell in [8, Section 4].

Now, we can consider the Blocki-Cegrell class in the global setting.
Definition 2.5. Let $\mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$ be the set of functions $\varphi \in \operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega)$ such that locally, on any small open holomorphic coordinate chart $U \subset X$, the psh function $\left.\varphi\right|_{U}+\rho_{U} \in \mathcal{D}(U)$, where $\rho_{U}$ is the local potential of $\omega$ on $U$ such that $\left.\varphi\right|_{U}+\rho_{U} \leq 0$.

It is easy to see that we have $\mathcal{D}(X, \omega) \subset D M A(X, \omega)$. Coman, Guedj, and Zeriahi characterized $\mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$ in [10, Section 3]. They found that $\mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$ is much smaller than $D M A(X, \omega)$.

[^0]:    ${ }^{1}$ In their results, it is not necessary for $\omega$ to be Kähler. They only require $\{\omega\}$ to be big.

Let $\varphi \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$ and $U \subset X$ be a holomorphic coordinate such that $\omega=d d^{c} g$ on $U$. Let $\chi \in C(X)$ such that $\operatorname{supp} \chi \Subset U$. Set $\varphi_{k}:=\max \{\varphi,-k\}$; then, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{X} \chi \mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi) & =\lim _{k} \int_{X} \chi\left(\omega+d d^{c} \varphi_{k}\right)^{n} \\
& =\lim _{k} \int_{U} \chi\left(d d^{c}\left(g+\varphi_{k}\right)\right)^{n}=\int_{U} \chi \mathrm{MA}(\varphi+g)
\end{aligned}
$$

by the definition of the complex Monge-Ampère operator. Hence,

$$
\chi \mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)=\chi \mathbf{1}_{U} \mathrm{MA}(\varphi+g)
$$

where $\mathbf{1}_{U} M A(\cdot)$ represents the complex Monge-Ampère operator in $U$. We will use this concept frequently and will not explain it in detail again.

By [4, Theorem 1.2], one has
Lemma 2.6. Let $\varphi \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$ and $\psi \in \operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega)$ such that $\psi \succeq \varphi$. Then, $\psi \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$.

And the following is derived from $[4,7]$ :
Lemma 2.7. Let $\varphi, \psi \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$. Then, $(1-t) \varphi+t \psi \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$ for $0 \leq t \leq 1$, which means that $\mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$ is a convex set.

Set $\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}\left(\varphi_{1}, \ldots, \varphi_{n}\right):=\left(\omega+d d^{c} \varphi_{1}\right) \wedge \ldots \wedge\left(\omega+d d^{c} \varphi_{n}\right), \varphi_{i} \in \operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega) \cap L^{\infty}(X)$. We then have the following property:

Proposition 2.8. Let $\varphi_{1}, \ldots, \varphi_{n} \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$ and $\varphi_{i}^{j} \in \operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega) \cap L^{\infty}(X)$ such that $\varphi_{i}^{j} \searrow \varphi_{i}$ as $j \rightarrow+\infty$; then, $\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}\left(\varphi_{1}^{j}, \ldots, \varphi_{n}^{j}\right)$ converges weakly to a Radon measure $\mu$, and the limit measure does not depend on the particular sequence. We denote $\mu$ by $\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}\left(\varphi_{1}, \ldots, \varphi_{n}\right)$.

Proof. The similar conclusion in the bounded hyperconvex domain $\Omega$ is a direct consequence of [8, Theorem 4.2]. The remaining work can be completed by finding a suitable coordinate and utilizing (2.1).

Let $\varphi_{1}, \ldots, \varphi_{n} \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$. We define $\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}\left(\varphi_{1}{ }^{\left(k_{1}\right)}, \ldots, \varphi_{n}{ }^{\left(k_{n}\right)}\right)$ as $\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}\left(\psi_{1}, \ldots, \psi_{n}\right)$, where $\psi_{1}=\ldots=\psi_{k_{1}}:=\varphi_{1}, \psi_{k_{1}+1}=\ldots=\psi_{k_{1}+k_{2}}:=\varphi_{2}, \ldots, \psi_{n}=\psi_{n-1}=\ldots=$ $\psi_{n-k_{n}}=\varphi_{n}$.

Corollary 2.9. Assume that $\varphi_{1}, \ldots, \varphi_{s} \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$. Then, for $0 \leq t_{1}, \ldots, t_{s} \leq 1$ such that $\sum_{i} t_{i}=1$, we have $\sum_{i} t_{i} \varphi_{i} \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$ and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{MA}_{\omega} & \left(\sum_{i} t_{i} \varphi_{i}\right) \\
& =\sum_{k_{i} \geq 0, k_{1}+\ldots+k_{s}=n} C_{k_{1}, \ldots, k_{s}} \cdot t_{1}^{k_{1}} \cdot \ldots \cdot t_{s}^{k_{s}} \cdot \mathrm{MA}_{\omega}\left(\varphi_{1}^{\left(k_{1}\right)}, \ldots, \varphi_{s}^{\left(k_{s}\right)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $C_{k_{1}, \ldots, k_{s}}:=\frac{n!}{k_{1}!\ldots \cdot k_{s}!}$.
Proof. By definition, it suffices to prove this result for bounded $\omega$-psh functions, which follows directly from the multilinear of Monge-Ampère operator.

2.3. Non-pluripolar energy. Let us now introduce the non-pluripolar energies.

Definition 2.10. We define the non-pluripolar energy of $\varphi \in \operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega)$ as

$$
E^{n p}(\varphi):=\frac{1}{k+1} \sum_{j=0}^{n-1} \int_{X} \varphi\left\langle\left(d d^{c} \varphi+\omega\right)^{j}\right\rangle \wedge \omega^{n-j}
$$

Then, we can define the finite energy class $\mathcal{G}(X, \omega):=\left\{\varphi \in \operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega): E^{n p}(\varphi)>\right.$ $-\infty\}$.

Note that $\varphi \in \mathcal{G}(X, \omega)$ iff $\varphi \in L^{1}\left(\left\langle\omega_{\varphi}^{k}\right\rangle \wedge \omega^{n-k}\right), k=0,1, \ldots, n-1$ since $\varphi$ is bounded from above. Hence, if $\varphi \in \mathcal{G}(X, \omega)$, we can define the currents

$$
\left[\omega+d d^{c} \varphi\right]^{p}:=\left(\omega+d d^{c} \varphi\right) \wedge\left\langle\omega_{\varphi}^{p-1}\right\rangle \text { and } S_{p}^{\omega}(\varphi):=\left[\omega+d d^{c} \varphi\right]^{p}-\left\langle\omega_{\varphi}^{p}\right\rangle
$$

for $p=1,2, \ldots, n$. In [2, Proposition 3.3], they showed that $\left[\omega+d d^{c} \varphi\right]^{p}$ and $S_{p}^{\omega}(\varphi)$ are well-defined globally closed positive currents on $X$ that only depend on the current $d d^{c} \varphi+\omega$ and not on the choice of $\omega$ as a Kähler representative in the class $[\omega]$.

There are two useful results follow from [2]:
Theorem 2.11. ([2, Theorem 6.8]) Assume that $\varphi \in \mathcal{G}(X, \omega)$ and that $\eta$ is a Kähler form in $[\omega]$ so that $\eta=\omega+d d^{c} g$, where $g$ is a smooth function on $X$. Let $\varphi_{l}:=\max \{\varphi, g-l\}$. Then, for $1 \leq p \leq n$, one has

$$
\left(\omega+d d^{c} \varphi_{l}\right)^{p} \rightarrow\left[\omega+d d^{c} \varphi\right]^{p}+\sum_{j=1}^{p-1} S_{j}^{\omega}(\varphi) \wedge \eta^{p-j}, l \rightarrow \infty
$$

Theorem 2.12. ([2, Theorem 1.11]) Let $(X, \omega)$ be a compact Kähler manifold of dimension $n$. Then,

$$
\mathcal{D}(X, \omega) \subset \mathcal{G}(X, \omega)
$$

In particular, $\mathcal{D}(X, \omega) \subset D M A(X, \omega) \cap \mathcal{G}(X, \omega)$.

# 3. The Class of $D M A(X, \omega) \cap \mathcal{G}(X, \omega)$ 

In this section, we assume that $(X, \omega)$ is a compact Kähler manifold of complex dimension $n$. Note that if $\varphi \in D M A(X, \omega) \cap \mathcal{G}(X, \omega)$, by the definition of the complex Monge-Ampère operator and Theorem 2.11, we have

$$
\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)=\left[\omega+d d^{c} \varphi\right]^{n}+\sum_{j=1}^{n-1} S_{j}^{\omega}(\varphi) \wedge \omega^{n-j}=\left\langle\omega_{\varphi}^{n}\right\rangle+\sum_{j=1}^{n} S_{j}^{\omega}(\varphi) \wedge \omega^{n-j}
$$

It may be helpful to consider the solution of the complex Monge-Ampère equation $\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)=\mu$ when $\mu$ is allowed to be a normalized measure with a pluripolar part. A similar idea was proposed in [2, Remark 11.13], but they did not consider terms with $S_{j}^{\omega}(\varphi) \wedge \omega^{n-j}, j=1, \ldots, n-1$.

In particular, when $(X, \omega)$ is a compact Kähler surface, the above argument becomes more interesting. Let $f \in C^{\infty}(X)$ and $C \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$so that $\eta:=C^{-1} d d^{c} f+\omega>$ 0 . Set $g:=C^{-1} f$ and $\varphi_{l}^{\prime}:=\max \{\varphi, g-l\}, \varphi_{l}:=\max \{\varphi,-l\}$. Since $\varphi_{l}^{\prime}, \varphi_{l} \in$ $\operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega) \cap L^{\infty}(X)$ and $\varphi_{l}^{\prime}, \varphi_{l}$ decrease to $\varphi$ as $l \rightarrow \infty$, it follows from Theorem 2.11 and the definition of the complex Monge-Ampère operator that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi) & =\left[\omega+d d^{c} \varphi\right]^{2}+S_{1}^{\omega}(\varphi) \wedge \omega \\
& =\left[\omega+d d^{c} \varphi\right]^{2}+S_{1}^{\omega}(\varphi) \wedge\left(\omega+d d^{c} g\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, for $w \in C^{\infty}(X)$, it follows from (3.2) that

$$
\int_{X} w d d^{\mathrm{c}} g \wedge S_{1}^{\omega}(\varphi)=\frac{1}{C} \int_{X} w d d^{\mathrm{c}} f \wedge S_{1}^{\omega}=0
$$

When $w=f$, we obtain $\int_{X}(\sqrt{-1} \partial f \wedge \bar{\partial} f) \wedge S_{1}^{\omega}(\varphi)=0, \forall f \in C^{\infty}(X)$. Then, we can construct a positive $(1,1)$-form $\alpha$ such that $\alpha>\omega$ and $\int_{X} \alpha \wedge S_{1}^{\omega}(\varphi)=0$. Hence $\int_{X} S_{1}^{\omega}(\varphi) \wedge \omega=0$, then we have $S_{1}^{\omega}(\varphi) \wedge \omega=0$, which means

$$
\left\langle\omega+d d^{\mathrm{c}} \varphi\right\rangle \wedge \omega=\left(\omega+d d^{\mathrm{c}} \varphi\right) \wedge \omega
$$

We thus obtain the following result:
Proposition 3.1. Let $(X, \omega)$ be a compact Kähler surface and $\varphi \in D M A(X, \omega) \cap$ $\mathcal{G}(X, \omega)$. Then,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi) & =\left[\omega+d d^{\mathrm{c}} \varphi\right]^{2}=\left\langle\omega+d d^{\mathrm{c}} \varphi\right\rangle \wedge\left(\omega+d d^{\mathrm{c}} \varphi\right) \\
& =d d^{\mathrm{c}} \varphi \wedge\left\langle\omega+d d^{\mathrm{c}} \varphi\right\rangle+\omega \wedge\left(\omega+d d^{\mathrm{c}} \varphi\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

In particular, when $\varphi \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$, the above formula holds.
Furthermore, for the class $\mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$, we have
Theorem 3.2. Let $\varphi_{1}, \ldots, \varphi_{n} \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$. Then, $\varphi_{1} \in L^{1}\left(\left\langle\omega_{\varphi_{2}} \wedge \ldots \wedge \omega_{\varphi_{n}}\right\rangle \wedge \omega\right)$.
If $X$ is a compact Kähler surface and $\varphi, \psi \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$, then we have

$$
\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi, \psi)=\frac{1}{2}\left[\left(\omega+d d^{\mathrm{c}} \varphi\right) \wedge\left\langle\omega+d d^{\mathrm{c}} \psi\right\rangle+\left(\omega+d d^{\mathrm{c}} \psi\right) \wedge\left\langle\omega+d d^{\mathrm{c}} \varphi\right\rangle\right]
$$

The proof needs the following Lemma:
Lemma 3.3. Let $\varphi$ be a quasi-psh function on $X$, and let $T$ be a positive closed $(n-1, n-1)$-current such that $\varphi \in L^{1}(\omega \wedge T)$. Then, for $\varphi_{j} \in C^{\infty}(X)$ such that $\varphi_{j} \searrow \varphi$, we have

$$
d d^{\mathrm{c}} \varphi_{j} \wedge T \rightarrow d d^{\mathrm{c}} \varphi \wedge T
$$

in the weak sense.
Proof of Theorem 3.2. $1^{\circ}$. We first prove that $\varphi_{1} \in L^{1}\left(\left\langle\omega_{\varphi_{2}} \wedge \ldots \wedge \omega_{\varphi_{n}}\right\rangle \wedge \omega\right)$. Without loss of generality, we can assume that $\varphi_{i} \leq 0, i=1, \ldots, n$.

It follows from Corollary 2.9 and Theorem 2.12 that

$$
\frac{1}{n}\left(\sum_{i} \varphi_{i}\right) \in L^{1}\left(\left\langle\left(\omega+d d^{\mathrm{c}} \frac{1}{n}\left(\sum_{i} \varphi_{i}\right)\right)^{n-1}\right\rangle \wedge \omega\right)
$$

By [14, Proposition 8.16], there exists $\varphi_{1}^{j} \in \operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega) \cap C^{\infty}(X)$ such that $\varphi_{1}^{j} \searrow$ $\varphi_{1}$ as $j \rightarrow+\infty$. Then, by the multilinearity of the non-pluripolar product and multinomial theorem, we obtain
$-\int_{X} \varphi_{1}^{j} \omega \wedge\left\langle\left(\omega+d d^{\mathrm{c}} \varphi_{2}\right) \wedge \ldots \wedge\left(\omega+d d^{\mathrm{c}} \varphi_{n}\right)\right\rangle \leq \int_{X} \varphi_{1}\left\langle\left(n \omega+d d^{\mathrm{c}}\left(\sum_{i} \varphi_{i}\right)\right)^{n-1}\right\rangle \wedge \omega$.
Applying the monotone convergence theorem, we obtain

$$
0 \leq-\int_{X} \varphi_{1} \omega \wedge\left\langle\left(\omega+d d^{\mathrm{c}} \varphi_{2}\right) \wedge \ldots \wedge\left(\omega+d d^{\mathrm{c}} \varphi_{n}\right)\right\rangle<+\infty
$$

$2^{\circ}$. Next, we prove that

$$
\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi, \psi)=\frac{1}{2}\left[\left(\omega+d d^{\mathrm{c}} \varphi\right) \wedge\left\langle\omega+d d^{\mathrm{c}} \psi\right\rangle+\left(\omega+d d^{\mathrm{c}} \psi\right) \wedge\left\langle\omega+d d^{\mathrm{c}} \varphi\right\rangle\right]
$$

By Corollary 2.9 with $t_{1}=t_{2}=\frac{1}{2}$ and Proposition 3.1, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi, \psi) & =2 \mathrm{MA}_{\omega}\left(\frac{1}{2}(\varphi+\psi)\right)-\frac{1}{2}\left(\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)+\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\psi)\right) \\
= & \frac{1}{2}\left(\omega \wedge\left(\omega+d d^{c} \varphi\right)+\omega \wedge\left(\omega+d d^{c} \psi\right)\right) \\
& -\frac{1}{2}\left(d d^{c} \varphi \wedge\left\langle\omega+d d^{c} \varphi\right\rangle+d d^{c} \psi \wedge\left\langle\omega+d d^{c} \psi\right\rangle\right) \\
& +\left(\left(d d^{c}(\varphi+\psi)\right) \wedge\left\langle\omega+2^{-1} d d^{c}(\varphi+\psi)\right\rangle\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, we can complete the proof of the theorem if we can show that

$$
\begin{gathered}
d d^{c}(\varphi+\psi) \wedge\left\langle\omega+2^{-1} d d^{c}(\varphi+\psi)\right\rangle \\
=\frac{1}{2}\left(d d^{c} \varphi \wedge\left\langle\omega+d d^{c} \varphi\right\rangle+d d^{c} \psi \wedge\left\langle\omega+d d^{c} \psi\right\rangle+d d^{c} \varphi \wedge\left\langle\omega+d d^{c} \psi\right\rangle+d d^{c} \psi \wedge\left\langle\omega+d d^{c} \varphi\right\rangle\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

Indeed, analogous to $1^{\circ}$, we can find smooth functions $\psi_{j}$ and $\varphi_{j}$ that decrease to $\psi$ and $\varphi$, respectively. Applying the multilinearity of the non-pluripolar product and Lemma 3.3, makes it straightforward to obtain the desired conclusion.

# 4. Solving the complex Monge-AMPère equation 

4.1. Cegrell-Lebesgue decomposition. First, let us recall the Cegrell-Lebesgue decomposition theorem in a bounded hyperconvex domain $\Omega \subset \mathbb{C}^{n}$.

Theorem 4.1. ([8, Theorem 5.11]) Let $\mu$ be a positive measure on $\Omega$. Then, $\mu$ can be decomposed into a regular positive (non-pluripolar) measure $\mu_{r}$, and the singular positive (pluripolar) measure $\mu_{s}$ has support on some pluripolar set such that

$$
\mu=\mu_{r}+\mu_{s}
$$

We claim that the Cegrell-Lebesgue decomposition of $\mu$ is unique. Indeed, suppose that $\mu_{r}^{\prime}$ and $\mu_{s}^{\prime}$ are other Cegrell-Lebesgue decompositions, and that

$$
\mu_{s}=\mathbf{1}_{\{u=-\infty\}} \mu_{s}=\mathbf{1}_{\{u=-\infty\}} \mu, \mu_{s}^{\prime}=\mathbf{1}_{\left\{u^{\prime}=-\infty\right\}} \mu_{s}^{\prime}=\mathbf{1}_{\left\{u^{\prime}=-\infty\right\}} \mu
$$

where $u, u^{\prime} \in \operatorname{PSH}(\Omega)$. Set $A:=\{u=-\infty\} \cup\left\{u^{\prime}=-\infty\right\}=\left\{u+u^{\prime}=-\infty\right\}$. For $\forall f \in C_{0}(\Omega)$, since $\int_{A} \mu_{r}=\int_{A} \mu_{r}^{\prime}=0$, we have

$$
\int f d \mu_{s}=\int \mathbf{1}_{A} f d \mu_{s}=\int_{A} f d \mu=\int \mathbf{1}_{A} f d \mu_{s}^{\prime}=\int f d \mu_{s}^{\prime}
$$

This means that $\mu_{s}=\mu_{s}^{\prime}$; hence, $\mu_{r}=\mu-\mu_{s}=\mu-\mu_{s}^{\prime}=\mu_{r}^{\prime}$.
Let $\left(X, \omega_{X}\right)$ be a compact complex manifold of complex dimension $n$ equipped with a Hermitian form, and let $\mu$ be a positive measure on $X$. Let $\left\{U_{i}, z_{i}\right\}_{i=1}^{N}$ be the holomorphic atlas of $X$ such that $z_{i}\left(U_{i}\right)$ is the unit ball of $\mathbb{C}^{n}$ and $\left\{\chi_{i}\right\}_{i=1}^{N}$ is the partition of unity of $\left\{U_{i}\right\}_{i}$. According to Theorem 4.1, we have $\chi_{i} \mu=\mu_{r}^{\prime}+\mu_{s}^{\prime}$ for each $i$, where $\mu_{r}^{\prime}$ is a positive non-pluripolar measure on $U_{i}$ and $\mu_{s}^{\prime}$ is supported on the set $\left\{u_{i}=-\infty\right\}, u_{i} \in \operatorname{PSH}\left(U_{i}\right)$. Set $\mu_{r}:=\sum_{i} \mu_{r}^{\prime}$ and $\mu_{s}:=\sum_{i} \mu_{s}^{\prime}$, we have the Cegrell-Lebesgue decomposition $\mu=\mu_{r}+\mu_{s}$ in the global setting.

By the same method as above, the decomposition is unique in the global setting. Furthermore, thanks to [15, Theorem 1.1], there exists $u \in \operatorname{PSH}\left(X, \omega_{X}\right)$ such that $\mu_{s}$ is supported on the set $\{u=-\infty\}$.

From the above discussion, we have the following result:

Corollary 4.2. Let $\left(X, \omega_{X}\right)$ be a compact complex manifold of complex dimension $n$ equipped with a Hermitian form. Let $\mu$ be a positive measure on $X$. Then, $\mu$ can be uniquely decomposed into a regular positive (non-pluripolar) measure $\mu_{r}$ and a singular positive (pluripolar) measure $\mu_{s}$ support on $\{u=-\infty\}, u \in \operatorname{PSH}\left(X, \omega_{X}\right)$ such that

$$
\mu=\mu_{r}+\mu_{s}
$$

Now, we return to the compact Kähler manifold $(X, \omega)$. From Corollary 4.2, for a normalized measure $\mu$, a natural idea is to decompose $\mu$ into regular and singular parts $\mu_{r}$ and $\mu_{s}$ and consider

$$
\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)_{r}=\mu_{r}, \mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)_{s}=\mu_{s}, \varphi \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)
$$

respectively. Fortunately, by [10, Corollary 1.8] we have:
Theorem 4.3. Let $\varphi \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$. Then

$$
\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)_{r}=\left\langle\omega_{\varphi}^{n}\right\rangle \text { and } \mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)_{s}=\mathbf{1}_{\{\varphi=-\infty\}} \mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)_{s}
$$

Then, we can provide:
Corollary 4.4. Let $\varphi, \psi \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$ such that $\varphi \preceq \psi$. Then,

$$
\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)_{s} \geq \mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\psi)_{s}
$$

Proof. Let $\left\{U_{i}, z_{i}\right\}_{i=1}^{N}$ be the holomorphic atlas of $X$ such that $z_{i}\left(U_{i}\right) \subset \mathbb{C}^{n}$ is the unit ball and $\omega=d d^{c} g_{i}$ on $U_{i}$, where $g_{i} \in C^{\infty} \cap L^{\infty} \cap \operatorname{PSH}\left(U_{i}\right)$. In each $U_{i}$, we have $\varphi+g_{i} \leq \psi+g_{i}+C$ for some $C>0$. Then, by using [1, Lemma 4.1], we have

$$
\mathbf{1}_{U_{i}} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{\varphi+g_{i}=-\infty\right\}} \mathrm{MA}\left(\varphi+g_{i}\right) \geq \mathbf{1}_{U_{i}} \mathbf{1}_{\left\{\psi+g_{i}=-\infty\right\}} \mathrm{MA}\left(\psi+g_{i}\right)
$$

Let $\left\{\chi_{i}\right\}_{i=1}^{N}$ be the partition of unity of $\left\{U_{i}\right\}$. Since $\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)=\sum_{i} \chi_{i} \mathbf{1}_{U_{i}} \mathrm{MA}\left(g_{i}+\varphi\right)$, by (4.2), we are done.

When $\varphi \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$, due to the uniqueness of the Cegrell-Lebesgue decomposition, equation (3.1) and Theorem 4.3 yield the following result.
Corollary 4.5. Let $\varphi \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$. Then,

$$
\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)_{r}=\left\langle\omega_{\varphi}^{n}\right\rangle \text { and } \mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)_{s}=\sum_{j=1}^{n} S_{j}^{\varphi}(\varphi) \wedge \omega^{n-j}
$$

4.2. Solving the complex Monge-Ampère equation in $\mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$. In this subsection, we assume $(X, \omega)$ is a Kähler manifold such that $\int_{X} \omega^{n}=1$.

We set a normalized measure $\mu=\mu_{r}+\mu_{s}$ on $X$ such that $\int_{X} \mu=1$. If there exists $\varphi \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$ such that $\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)=\mu$, it follows from Corollary 4.2 and Theorem 4.3 that

$$
\int_{X}\left\langle\omega_{\varphi}^{n}\right\rangle=\int_{X} \mu_{r} \text { and } \mathbf{1}_{\{\varphi=-\infty\}} \mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)=\mu_{s}
$$

Then we have
Proposition 4.6. Assume that $\varphi \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$ and $\mu_{s}=\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)_{s}$. Then, for $\psi \in \operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega)$ so that $\varphi \preceq \psi \preceq P_{\omega}[\varphi]$, we have $\mathrm{MA}(\psi)_{s}=\mu_{s}$. Furthermore, if $\psi \succeq \varphi$ so that $\mathrm{MA}(\psi)_{s}=\mu_{s}$, then we have $\psi \preceq P_{\omega}[\varphi]$.

Proof. Assume that $\psi \in \operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega)$ such that $\varphi \preceq \psi \preceq P_{\omega}[\varphi]$. By Proposition 2.1 and Lemma 2.6, we have $\psi \in \mathcal{E}\left(X, \omega, P_{\omega}[\varphi]\right) \cap \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$. Applying Corollary 4.4, we obtain

$$
\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)_{s} \geq \mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\psi)_{s}
$$

Note that we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{X} \mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\psi)_{s} & =1-\int_{X} \mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\psi)_{r}=1-\int_{X}\left\langle\omega_{\psi}^{n}\right\rangle \\
& =1-\int_{X}\left\langle\omega_{\varphi}^{n}\right\rangle=1-\int_{X} \mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)_{r}=\int_{X} \mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)_{s}
\end{aligned}
$$

where we used the definition of $\mathcal{E}\left(X, \omega, P_{\omega}[\varphi]\right)$ and Theorem 4.3. By comparing the total mass, we obtain $\mu_{s}=\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)_{s}=\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}\left(P_{\omega}[\varphi]\right)_{s}$.

If $\psi \succeq \varphi$ so that $\mathrm{MA}(\psi)_{s}=\mathrm{MA}(\varphi)_{s}$, then we have $\int_{X}\left\langle\omega_{\psi}^{n}\right\rangle=\int_{X}\left\langle\omega_{\varphi}^{n}\right\rangle$. It follows from Proposition 2.3 (ii). that $\psi \preceq P_{\omega}[\varphi]$.

Set $\nu=\nu_{r}+\mu_{s}$. If $\nu_{r}$ satisfies $\int_{X} \nu_{r}=1-\int_{X} \mu_{s}$ and $\nu=f \omega^{n}$ for some $f \in$ $L^{p}(\omega), p>1$, it follows from [11, Theorem 5.20] that there exists $\psi \in \operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega)$ such that

$$
\psi \simeq P_{\omega}[\varphi] \text { and } \mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\psi)_{r}=\left\langle\omega_{\psi}^{n}\right\rangle=\nu_{r}
$$

By Lemma 2.6 and Proposition 4.6, we have $\psi \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$ and $\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\psi)_{s}=\mu_{s}$. We thus obtain

$$
\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\psi)=\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\psi)_{r}+\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\psi)_{s}=\left\langle\omega_{\psi}^{n}\right\rangle+\mu_{s}=\nu_{r}+\mu_{s}
$$

In summary, we obtain the following Theorem.
Theorem 4.7. Let $(X, \omega)$ be a compact Kähler manifold of complex dimension $n$ such that $\int_{X} \omega^{n}=1$, and let $\mu_{s}$ be a pluripolar measure on $X$ supported on some pluripolar set. If there exists $\varphi \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$ such that $\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)_{s}=\mu_{s}$, then for all $0 \leq f \in L^{p}\left(\omega^{n}\right), p>1$ such that $\int_{X} f \omega^{n}=1-\int_{X} \mu_{s}$, there exists a $\psi \in \operatorname{PSH}(X, \omega)$ that is the solution of the equation

$$
\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\psi)=f \omega^{n}+\mu_{s}, \psi \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)
$$

4.3. Application to compact Kähler surfaces. Let $(X, \omega)$ be a compact Kähler surface such that $\int_{X} \omega^{2}=1$, and let $\mu$ be a measure on $X$ so that $\mu=\mu_{s}$. If there exists $\varphi \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$ such that $\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi)=\mu$ (e.g. the quasi-psh Green functions, see [9]), then, for $\forall s \in[0,1]$, it follows from Corollary 2.9, (3.3), and Theorem 3.2 that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(s \varphi) & =(1-s)^{2} \mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(0)+2(1-s) s \mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(0, \varphi)+s^{2} \mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(\varphi) \\
& =(1-s)^{2} \omega^{2}+2(1-s) s \omega \wedge\left\langle\omega+d d^{c} \varphi\right\rangle+s^{2} \mu_{s}
\end{aligned}
$$

This means that $\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}(s \varphi)_{s}=s^{2} \mu$. Therefore, for any $t \in[0,1]$ and any $0 \leq f \in$ $L^{p}\left(\omega^{n}\right), p>1$ such that $\int_{X} f \omega^{2}=1$, by Theorem 4.7, there exists $\psi_{f, t} \in \mathcal{D}(X, \omega)$ that satisfies

$$
\mathrm{MA}_{\omega}\left(\psi_{f, t}\right)=(1-t) f \omega^{2}+t \mu
$$

abstract:
In this note, we solve the complex Monge-Amp\`ere equation for measures with
a pluripolar part in compact K\"ahler manifolds. This result generalizes the
classical results obtained by Cegrell in bounded hyperconvex domains. We also
discuss the properties of the complex Monge-Amp\`ere operator in some special
cases.
